div.a: 2 The Early Stages of the Project

div.h1: First We Feel Then We Fall: James Joyce’s Finnegans Wake as an interactive video application

div.div: Institute of English Studies, Jagiellonian University in Kraków, Poland
Search for other works by this author on:
Academy of Fine Arts in Warsaw, Poland
Search for other works by this author on:
Digital Scholarship in the Humanities, Volume 32, Issue suppl_2, December 2017, Pages ii124–ii134, https://doi.org/10.1093/llc/fqx027

div.p: Katarzyna Bazarnik, Jakub Wróblewski, First We Feel Then We Fall: James Joyce’s Finnegans Wake as an interactive video application, Digital Scholarship in the Humanities, Volume 32, Issue suppl_2, December 2017, Pages ii124–ii134, https://doi.org/10.1093/llc/fqx027

optgroup.label: Search within this journal
optgroup.option: All Digital Scholarship in the Humanities

optgroup.label: Search within this journal
optgroup.option: All Digital Scholarship in the Humanities

section.p: The article describes First We Feel Then We Fall, a multichannel, interactive video application, which is a multimedia adaptation of James Joyce’s Finnegans Wake. It offers the viewers a portmanteau-like audiovisual experience resembling the experience of reading Joyce’s enigmatic, multilingual dream-like narrative. Through an audiovisual format consisting of simultaneously running streams, it proposes an intermedial translation of hypertextuality and simultaneity of Finnegans Wake. The Wakean imagery, euphonies, rhythms, and polyphonic contexts are rendered into four narrative strands, or ‘plots’. Networks of linguistic, historical, symbolic, and mathematical meanings entailed in Wakean puns are transposed into a dynamic audiovisual structure that the audience can co-shape in the process of interactive viewing. They can switch at will between four simultaneous streams of film clips accompanied by sound (and optional captions with the Finnegans Wake text). The interactive and immersive nature of First We Feel Then We Fall goes beyond previous cinematic adaptations of Joyce’s novel. It is the advance of digital technologies that have enabled us to approach complexity of Finnegans Wake in this novel way.

div.p: Finnegans Wake is the last, most mysterious book by the Irish writer James Joyce. Usually described as a novel, it is a fascinating text written primarily in English fused with several dozen other languages. Originating from a few sketches inspired by ancient Irish myths, it grew into an oneiric narrative, often interpreted as a stream of consciousness of somebody at the verge of sleep, or death (Hayman, 1978; Bishop, 1986; Begnal, 1988). It can be also seen as a textual collage in which the author wove together stories, passages, and phrases he picked up from historical and literary texts, sacred scriptures, encyclopedic entries, and even the popular press (Atherton, 1959; Fordham, 2007; Crispi et al., 2007). They were often lifted verbatim from these sources and ‘reamalgamerge[d]’ (Joyce, 1939/1989: 49) in the 17 years long process.

It features a Dublin pub owner Humphrey Chimpden Earwicker (usually acronymized as HCE), his wife Anna Livia Plurabelle (known as ALP), their twin sons Shem and Shaun, and their daughter Issy, but their identities are dubious, fuzzy, and spectral. They travel through space and time to discover the truth about a scandalous incident in Phoenix Park in which HCE was implicated, and to deliver a letter written by ALP in his defense. Drawn into a whirlpool of the past, they metamorphose into historical and legendary figures, as well as characters of alphabetic writing, and even a hill, a river, a cloud, a tree, and a stone (Campbell and Robinson, 1959; Glasheen, 1977; Bazarnik, 2011). The story of HCE’s fall overlaps with the story of a drunken bricklayer Tim Finnegan who fell off a ladder but was resurrected when whisky splashed on his face during a fight at his wake. This fuses with the original Fall, sexual falls of politicians and celebrities, Napoleon and Wellington’s encounter on the battlefield of Waterloo, Tristan and Iseult’s romance, a hen discovering an ancient manuscript in a rubbish heap, and more. Fundamentally, the dense texture of the book is built up from the same stories that resurface in an almost obsessive manner, ‘[t]eems of times and happy returns. The seim anew. Ordovico or viricordo’ (Joyce, 1939/1989: 215). Thus, drawing on a cyclical vision of history, Finnegans Wake can be seen as a textual merry-go-round that begins mid-sentence and ends with another one broken in the middle, which finds its continuation on the first page:

A way a lone a last a loved a long the
riverrun, past Eve and Adam's, from swerve of shore to bend of bay, brings us by a commodius vicus of recirculation back to Howth Castle and Environs (Joyce, 19391989: 628; 3)
div.h3: 1.2 Finnegans Wake and the anticipation of the digital audience
div.p: In such an experimental way, Donald Theall observes, Joyce was keen to ‘explore poetically the accelerating modes of synaesthesia, the orchestration of the arts and contextual fluidity which would provide a new language, a new sense of structure and a probing of the depths of the social as well as the individual unconscious in dreams that had always already provided the sense of art as virtuality’ (Theall, 2003–2004). In consequence, his non-linear, accretive method of composition has affected the traditional model of the linearly progressing narrative, and resulted in what David Hayman calls the ‘nodal structure’ (1978/1979; see also Hart, 1962). That is, some passages are dense clusters of several narratives or motifs, styles, and languages, interlaid with less complex discourse that functions as a kind of connective tissue. Scholars such as Theall and Louis Armand link this explicitly with the poetics of the Web, considering the Wake an anticipatory conceptualization of the fluid and dynamic nature of the hypertext (Theall, 1997, 2000, 2010; Armand, 2003). As Laurent Milesi (2004: 68) aptly describes, ‘…the Wake-as-dynamic palimpsest already prefigures its own hypertext (and the invention thereof)—with the pun as the node for its material implementation, each semic unit becoming thus as link of sorts’. Additionally, Joyce foregrounded the visual and material qualities of print, thereby illuminating multimodality of language in its various medial embodiments: sound, image, and even gesture. Thus, the subtly multimodal dimension of Finnegans Wake provides another parallel between this book and the digital media.

Joyce, 1939/1989 Due to these features, the book challenges familiar reading habits. The reader may feel daunted by its density, or encouraged to explore it in an engaged, interactive way. As Derek Attridge explains,
Reading Joyce is an activity which extends from the small-scale pleasures of appreciating the skilful organization and complex suggestiveness of a single sentence or a phrase to the large-scale project of constructing a model that will impart a unity (provisionally, at least) to an entire book or the entire œuvre, or even the entire œuvre together with the history, personal and public, of which it is a part. Reading a text of Joyce’s can be compared to playing a piece of music—it can be done rapidly, skipping over opaque or repetitious passages to gain a sense of the longer-range patters and developments, or slowly, savouring the words, puzzling over the conundrums, following up the cross-references. (Attridge, 1990: 3)

So the traditional, linear progression usually gives way to less systematic reading procedures. It often happens that readers flip quickly through more obscure pages to stop at sections where a familiar phrase or detail catches their attention, and prompts them to form a conceptual link with some previously read passages. Consequently, they leaf forward or backward in search for them. Their movement through the textual space traces a meandering, wayward path. This way of reading resembles browsing Web pages, and following hyperlinks one finds interesting. Another, almost contrary, technique mentioned by Attridge consists in focusing on a single word or phrase, and ‘unpacking’ the portmanteau into several ‘meanings’ co-present in it (1990: 3), as if the readers were zooming in on a detail of a digital image. The delving into the ‘contextual fluidity’ of a single pun resembles exploring a cloud of tags on a Web page. The emerging senses appear like ‘a multiplicity without the imposition of a principle of domination’ (Bolter, 1994: 112), which strengthens the parallel between the Wake and the hypertext. Discussing Joyce’s book as ‘Hyperwake 3D’, Laurent Milesi notes how these two reading protocols constitute ‘the Wake-as-hypertext’, i.e. the kind of text which ‘opens up the possibility of a cyberspatial, cybersthetic dimension’ emerging from ‘the random navigation by the Wakean cybernaut (cf. kubernan: to steer, guide, govern) among organised strands of perceptual, sensorial data which shape new potential virtual realities with every new Wakean cross-fertilisation’ (Milesi 2004: 69). In Digital Modernism, Jessica Pressman (2014: 105) observes that ‘the web has itself been understood as a structural implementation of associative cognition, a representation of the way the human mind works’. No wonder then that Finnegans Wake, read, as it often is, as a representation of a dreaming mind governed by the logic of free associations, prompts mechanisms and habits of reading/reception similar to those fostered by the digital media.

Contemporary audiences are tuned to and trained in such reading protocols. Significantly, since the release of Joyce’s work from the copyright restraints in 2012, a number of online projects have emerged, aimed at explicating, illuminating, or creatively reworking the Wake’s innumerable riches,1 which Theall (2000) so perceptively predicted in the early days of the Internet. Following Theall and others, Krzysztof Loska (1999: 12) claims that Joyce aimed at creating a new language capable of expressing the complexity and multidimensionality of the modern world dominated by the audiovisual, electric media. As Billy Mills (2015), a Guardian critic and literary blogger, observed recently, ‘perhaps Finnegans Wake needed the web to become easily readable. Maybe Joyce’s multiple concurrent layers of meaning and rejection of linearity need hypertext and online reading habits to open them up to a wider audience’.
div.h2: 2 The Early Stages of the Project
div.p: The suggestive richness of Finnegans Wake inspired Jakub Wróblewski, a graphic designer, multimedia artist, and lecturer at the Academy of Fine Arts in Warsaw, to develop its cinematic, multimedia adaptation. Fascinated by the Polish translation of the book, which came out in 2012, he quickly realized that the complexity of its linguistic, typographic, and architectural codes (Bazarnik, 2011) makes Joyce’s oneiric work akin to film, which as ‘it is now generally accepted (…) is a plural, complex, simultaneously static and changing event, produced by the filmmakers who put it together and the audience members who view it’ (Kolker, 2000:13). His other inspiration stemmed from a parallel between Joyce’s book and cinema, as both are often compared to dream (Bateman and Schmidt 2012: 21). Yet the specificity of Joyce’s elusive, associative, multi-plotted narrative posed a challenge even to the cinematic storytelling techniques, if only for the fact that the text problematizes the very concept of the beginning, middle, and end. Other challenges consisted in selecting a storyline that could provide the basis of the cinematic narration, and finding a way to represent complex, and equivocal personalities of the main heroes. Finally, it was necessary to think up a way of rendering the nodal structure, and the multifaceted texture of its polyglot language, using the audiovisual means.

Grappling with the obscure, enigmatic text, Wróblewski spotted the phrase: ‘First we feel then we fall’ (Joyce, 1939/1989: 627). It attracted his attention with lyricism, as well as aptness in capturing the experience of reading Joyce’s book, which frequently results in failure as regards its understanding and interpretation. More universally, the phrase can be related to the human condition, signaling how people’s emotional responses underline seemingly reasonable decisions that may also end up in disaster. He decided to use it as the title for his project.

Wróblewski commenced his work in 2014 with preparing a mind map that is a physical installation containing elements instrumental for the future adaptation.2 It consisted of six major parts (Fig. 1). The first one pertained to different interpretations based on critical sources on Finnegans Wake, and included critical books, articles, analyses, and dictionaries. The second one was the text of the book itself, reprinted in an enlarged form (297 × 420 cm), leaving ample space for textual and visual annotations that soon began to fill in the wide margins. (Later they provided an input for the final, multi-plotted storyboard; Fig. 2.) Another component consisted of animations representing the schematic interrelations among the characters, based on Adaline Glasheen’s A Third Census of Finnegans Wake (1977), and Krzysztof Loska’s (2000) summaries of most popular interpretations of the book. The fourth part comprised a collection of various objects, props, and fetishes, found or purchased, that were to be used in the future filming (Fig. 3). The artist intended them to represent motifs, characters, and style of Finnegans Wake. The sixth, very important component of the installation, consisted of 89 individual stills, that is, 40 × 80 mm collages (Fig. 4) that served Wróblewski as a kind of handy notes for specific shots he envisaged for the future film.

img.alt: Mind map in the form of the installation

div.p: Mind map in the form of the installation

img.alt: The collage stills, a part of the physical mind map of the project

div.p: The collage stills, a part of the physical mind map of the project

Working on the collages offered Wróblewski ample opportunities to test the frames, perspectives, types of shots, texture, and color. He used archival photographs, newspaper and magazine photos, and book illustrations to create them. Resorting to original photographs presupposes the existence of real objects and events recorded for posterity, thanks to the deliberate decision of a photographer; this was an important factor for the artist who invested them with symbolic value. In fact, using them to compose the stills, Wróblewski resorted to a method comparable to Joyce’s appropriating ‘found texts’. Similar to that was also his use of 8-mm and super 8-mm roll films, which he serendipitously found in a nearby garden, discovered in second-hand shops, and purchased at online auctions with the intention to use them in the project. Fifteen of them, containing a history of an anonymous family, constituted the final, sixth part of the installation. The people featuring in these obscure, old documentaries provided the visual embodiments to the Wakean family: HCE, ALP, and their children, Shem, Shaun, and Issy.

The installation as well as two teasers (Wróblewski, 2015, 2016) produced at the early stages of the project played a role similar to sections of Work in Progress Joyce published in the 1930s prior to the complete publication of Finnegans Wake in May 1939. They allowed the artist to test his visions, as well as intrigue prospective audiences, and alert them to the upcoming piece.

Soon it became clear that a collaboration with a Joyce specialist became indispensable. If the adaptation was to take a more definite shape, it needed to be based on a plot or plots that could be used to prepare a storyboard, as Wróblewski was still groping in the dark. So he contacted Katarzyna Bazarnik, a Joyce scholar who had worked on the spatial structure of Finnegans Wake,3 and invited her to collaborate with him on the project.

Bazarnik prepared three ‘narrative threads’ composed of passages that focused, first, on the Wakean family; second, on the media and technology; and finally, on the mysterious letter written allegedly by ALP in defense of her husband, or perhaps by Shem, and delivered by Shaun, the other twin. The authors of the adaptation decided to use the last plot line, dubbed ‘Traumscrapt’ (Joyce, 1939/1977: 623). Its working title hints at the affinity between dream (German Traum), film, and Joyce’s book as a dream narrative.4 It consisted of thirty-two passages of varied length arranged according to the logic of ‘verbivocovisual’ associations (Joyce, 1939/1989: 341) rather than according to the pagination of the book (Fig. 5). This method was akin to Eisenstein’s (1959: 101) principle of dynamic editing, which presupposes a compositional scaffolding within which particular cinematic (narrative) segments are distributed according to a plot and to the principles of contrast and association.

img.alt: Thirty-two passages forming the ‘script’ for the adaptation

div.p: Thirty-two passages forming the ‘script’ for the adaptation

img.alt: Thirty-two passages forming the ‘script’ for the adaptation

div.p: Thirty-two passages forming the ‘script’ for the adaptation

The ‘Traumscrapt’ excerpts come from the following pages of the Wake: 1 (pp. 627–28)/2 (p. 3)/3 (p. 13)/4 (p. 3)/5 (p. 55)/6 (p. 18)/7 (p. 32)/8 (p. 6)/9 (p. 114)/10 (pp. 623–24)/11 (pp. 52–55)/12 (p. 247)/13 (p. 226)/14 (pp. 266–67)/15 (p. 104)/16 (pp. 93–94)/17 (p. 107)/18 (pp. 118–19)/19 (p. 112)/20 (p. 109)/21 (p. 112)/22 (p. 18)/23 (p. 18)/24 (pp. 123–24)/25 (pp. 599–600)/26 (p. 213)/27 (pp. 215–16)/28 (p. 308)/29 (p. 410)/30 (p. 423)/31 (pp. 613–14)/32 (p. 19). They provide the narrative scaffolding, while the cinematic clips based on them constitute counterparts of Wakean nodes (Hayman, 1978/1979) or semic units (Milesi, 2004: 68).

This sequence is preserved on the First We Feel Then We Fall Web site, where the clips are presented in four rows of eight small ‘windows’ that function as the menu, or a visual table of contents (Fig. 6). Such a two-dimensional grid does not immediately impose any strictly predetermined order.5 Hence, the viewers are prompted to choose freely, that is to apply their own dynamic editing when selecting the number and sequence of clips to be watched. Their exploration resembles following parallel plots of Finnegans Wake, which develop in non-linear ways and can be traversed like a maze, or a hypertext (Theall, 2003–2004), depending on which story the reader decides to trace. This corresponds with the vision of Joyce’s book as a kind of database of narratives: world histories, myths, legends, and gossips, as if stored under archetypal labels such as: unhappy love, seduction, father–son conflict, brotherly rivalry, death and resurrection, etc. It is almost as if, through its stratified and nodal composition, Joyce’s book offered a resolution to the apparent opposition between the logic of narrative and that of the database (Manovich, 2001: 225). By resorting to layouts and navigation mechanisms typical for the Web, this adaptation makes this tension in the Wake more apparent. As Jessica Pressman (2014: 113) notes with regard to ‘Ithaca’ episode of Ulysses, this ‘reminds us that the way we approach and access information—that is, the way we read—always happens through media that mediate’. At the same time, by offering its audience a possibility of dynamic editing, the adaptation testifies how Joyce’s work envisaged and anticipated ergodic reading practices fostered by the digital media.

img.alt: The visual menu (table of contents) of FWFTWF

div.p: The visual menu (table of contents) of FWFTWF

img.alt: The visual menu (table of contents) of FWFTWF

div.p: The visual menu (table of contents) of FWFTWF

div.h3: 3.2 The structure of the Web site
div.p:
The visual menu described above is the major component of the project Web site: http://www.firstwefeelthenwefall.com/, which consists of a series of boards the user can slide up and down. It begins with a teaser, followed by the title page, information about the authors, and partner institutions. The next two boards contain a brief description of Finnegans Wake, and a quotation from the book, serving as the motto of the project: ‘The meandertale, aloss and again, of our old Heidenburgh in the days when Head-in-Clouds walked the earth’ (Joyce, 1939/1989: 18). This is followed by an audio description and an animation of Umberto Eco’s (1994: 141) diagram showing the component parts of the word ‘meandertal’. His visual analysis of the portmanteau is suggestive of the waywardness of narrative threads running through Joyce’s book, which the authors wanted to render in their adaptation. As Wróblewski and Bazarnik (2016) explain on the project Web site:
Included by Umberto Eco in ‘The Aesthetics of Chaosmos’ (Eco 1989), this diagram shows how MEANDERTALE, one of innumerable puns making up the textual labirynth of Finnegans Wake, can be unpacked into three separate words. The image represents a network connecting meander, tale, and Neandertal, which combine to suggest a cluster of meanings. This Wakean pun clues us how to read the book: as a story wandering waywardly, looping backward and flashing forward, into the pre-historic past, and the origins of the human species. Working on the logic of associations, it hints at different interpretative paths, visualised by the wavy lines of the diagram. But at the same time it suggests that a single reading is impossible, and the only true sense is unattainable.

After these brief introductions, the users are given instructions how to begin the viewing, and how to move between multiple tracks in each of the thirty-two clips. The final board contains the credits, and information about sponsors, and supporting institutions.

As was flagged above, readers approach Finnegans Wake in different ways: as an experimental narrative, as a representation of the stream of consciousness, as a series of linguistic or cultural puzzles, or as a sort of music to be enjoyed in reading out loud, etc. While working on the project, the present authors took into consideration these interpretations, as well as the liberal reading protocols. They aimed to offer a counterpart to the browsing of the paper book in search for thematic or linguistic hyperlinking, and intensive close reading discussed in the beginning of this article. Most of all, they wanted to create an experience comparable to that of reading Joyce’s book. To do so, they needed to engage the viewers in a similar manner.

Apart from offering the film menu as a grid of thirty-two clickable ‘windows’, they decided to split each clip into three, four, or occasionally five tracks among which the user can switch at will. Each of them has its own sound track that is based on the same text but enriched with unique sound effects. Thus, for example, in the ‘opening’ track (the first one in the top left-hand corner), the first soundtrack features a female voice performing ALP’s final monologue in an emotional but fairly natural way. However, it accompanies for a considerable length multiple, overlapping images of ALP’s face. The second track contains several echoing, overlapping female voices accompanying undistorted, single images. In the third track, the woman’s voice pronounces the words with considerable difficulty, murmurs, chants, or otherwise plays with their sound, while the fourth track is accompanied by the sound of the sea overlaid with experimental, ambience music and no discernible words at all. This is another way of translating the Wake’s multilingual complexity into the cinematic (multi)medium.

The film clips constitute a kind of intersemiotic translation (or remediation, to use Bolter’s term) in which semantic complexity of the pun is decomposed or recomposed into four simultaneously running audiovisual tracks. Finally, it can be argued that the density of Joyce’s portmanteaux corresponds to the multimodal complexity of the clips that are combinations of different semiotic media and codes. They are composed of:
Kinetic images (original footage featuring all kinds of cinematic shots: scenes, close-ups; 2D and three-dimensional (3D) animations,6 stills, collages, photos, graphics inspected by the camera, professional and amateur documentaries, and archival materials, including an early animated film about Humpty Dumpty). To ensure cohesion of such versatile visual material, the images are black and white. However, some of them were digitally modified to add effects of granularity, three-dimensionality, and in two cases—color (this is justified by the content: the reference to the rainbow girls). The video formats include 4K, HD, and DV. The films were recorded with the use of Canon 5D MarkII, Panasonic Lumix GH4, Sony Fx7E, GoPro, and edited in 1920 × 850 PX format. Filming and editing were mainly done by Jakub Wróblewski, with the contribution of Jaśmina Wójcik.7
Sound (voices reading the Wakean text: in a natural and performative manner, and in different accents, moaning, whispering, chanting; combined with natural sounds (the sea, the rain, and the river), ambient music, and special sound effects composed by Rafał Ryterski of the Chopin Academy of Music in Warsaw). Sections 1, 15, 22, 26, and 27 of the ‘Traumscrapt’ feature female voices (read by Katarzyna Bazarnik and Weronika Lewandowska), those numbered 2–14, 16–25, and 28–32 have the male voice (read brilliantly in different accents by Martin Siemieński), whereas in Section 12, there are both female and male voices (Lewandowska and Siemieński).8
Text (the viewers can switch on the subscript to simultaneously watch a clip and read the text of Finnegans Wake used in the soundtrack).

So the synesthetic effect mentioned by Theall with regard to Joyce’s language is achieved through the use of the multimedia, and multimodality. However, on the visual level, the audience encounters the process reverse to the Wakean compression. The linguistic puns are as if refracted into the different semantic modes, and even visual tracks, if not story lines. They run simultaneously, but though the viewers may switch between them at will, the tracks can be watched only one at a time, as if to demonstrate the mechanism of foregrounding and backgrounding that is constantly at work when one considers a Wakean pun. This resembles looking at a multistable perceptual phenomenon,9 when our attention switches between two different, often contradictory interpretations of a perceived objects that are foregrounded one after the other but can never be seen simultaneously. In the application, the attention switch is actually performed haptically, by clicking on a selected track.

The fundamentally open structure resulting from the non-hierarchical arrangement of the film clips and their multitrack composition has prevented the authors of the adaptation from creating the ‘final’ version of narrative. Switching freely between the segments, and within them between the tracks, turns the viewing into a dynamic, associative editing carried out by the viewer–user. Such an explorative, ergodic approach to the cinematic material is emerging in contemporary documentary projects in which the audiences are offered a repository of footage to choose from (Flynn, 2014). But it seems that such openness constitutes a fundamental feature of Joyce’s original dream-like novel. By foregrounding this, First We Feel Then We Fall goes beyond previous cinematic adaptations of Joyce’s novel, which though visually rich, nevertheless offered a single narrative line.10 Moreover, it illuminates perceptual and cognitive processes activated by reading Finnegans Wake. It is only the advance of digital technologies that has enabled us to approach complexity of Finnegans Wake in this novel way.

1 Suffice us to mention only a few, just to illustrate a diversity of creative ways to explicate or remediate Joyce’s work: glosses of Finnegans Wake at http://www.finwake.com/; Finnegans Wake Extensible Elucidation Treasury at http://www.fweet.org/; Finneganowizje at http://finneganowizje.tumblr.com/; and Wake in Progress. Illustrations to Finnegans Wake at http://www.wakeinprogress.com/ (all accessed 29 October 2016).

2 The installation was presented during the exhibition ‘Czym się zajmujesz?’ (What are you working on?), featuring selected projects of the faculty members of the Academy of Fine Arts in Warsaw, held in the autumn of 2014 in ‘Salon Akademii’ Gallery.

3 Bazarnik was also involved in a theater adaptation of Joyce’s fiction called Finnegans Make (dir. Zenon Fajfer; premiered at James Joyce Summer School in Dublin, 22 July 1996). In 2012 together with Fajfer, she was the co-editor of Finneganów tren, the Polish translation of Finnegans Wake by Krzysztof Bartnicki.
4 An exploration of the theme of trauma, evident in the pun, and its relation to the cinematic and literary media goes beyond the scope of the present article.

5 The same type of layout is used, for example, in online anthologies of electronic literature, cf. Electronic Literature Collection 1, 2, and 3 http://collection.eliterature.org/1/ (October 2006), http://collection.eliterature.org/2/ (February 2011), and http://collection.eliterature.org/2/ (February 2016)
6 Visual materials for the animations were obtained from the Library of Trinity College Dublin, and Zurich James Joyce Foundation.
7 Mateusz Machalski was responsible for designing the logo, and typography of the project; Piotr Welk and Anna Płonka prepared 3D animations, including those of the Book of Kells.
K—Katarzyna Bazarnik
W—Weronika Lewandowska
M—Martin Siemieński

9 Multistable perceptual phenomena refer to visual, but also auditory, phenomena in which an object is perceived as ambiguous, and attention oscillates between two different, often contradictory interpretations of the perceived object, as is the case in the well-known image of a young woman–old hag; other visual examples include the duck–rabbit, chalice–two faces, and the Neckermann cube.
10 Cf. Mary Ellen Bute’s Passages from James Joyce's Finnegans Wake.
